This review has been made during the Year of Prophecy's second expansion, Renegade. Would I recommend Destiny 2? Yes, BUT... not for disgruntled veterans of the game and only for new players that are patient with self-control. This review is specifically aimed to explain to new players my thoughts of this live-service looter-shooter MMO. If you plan on dipping your toes into Destiny 2's free-to-play economy as a test drive then expect the game to demand you to play at your best and learn the mechanics, and I will explain which game expansions are worth buying close to the end of my review. That aside, I will explain the gameplay expectations, the pros and the cons of this game series.

I would describe Destiny 2 as a sci-fi first-person (sometimes third-person) looter shooter where you cast magical abilities on cooldowns. To brief you on the the gameplay, you will be doing specific activities to obtain specific gear like weapons and armor pieces. Most of the time you will be doing short repeatable missions or battling other players competitively in order to grow power equipment and watch your level go up. There are three main classes (the Titan warrior class, the Hunter rogue class, the Warlock mage class), and you start with three swappable light-infused subclasses. You will be using weapons with their own elements like the neutral Kinetic element, the three light elements (Arc, Solar, Void) and the two dark elements (Stasis, Strand). You have three weapon slots which are your Kinetic slot (Kinetic, Stasis and Strand only), the Special slot (Arc, Solar and Void only) and the Power slot (any element using heavy ammo only). Along with your weapons your character will have rechargeable abilities that are the grenade ability, the melee ability and the class ability (Titan barricade, Hunter dodge, Warlock rift) depending on the subclass element. There are character modifiers such as subclass fragments, exotic weapons and armors that can change your playstyle on how you battle enemies or other players. You will be traveling around the solar system battling a multitude of alien races on various planets with their own special attacks and tactics.

I will start with the pros. The biggest factor of Destiny 2 is honestly the gameplay loop, graphics, sound design, and the world building they have set up. The opening tutorial does a good job getting the players settled into the world with a brief introduction and getting them into the action immediately. The game feel of your weapons and your character powers feel incredibly good in terms of reaction, special effects and even the audio sounds. The game is damn beautiful even on a middle-tier computer since it was designed for the PS4/XBO era of game consoles with amazing cinematics and fantastical environments. While I can't remember any specific music in this game to hum to, the complex score is an astounding orchestral ensemble that always sets the appropriate mood for any story beats and atmosphere. This game is great for those that want to get invested into the world of Destiny with the myriad of survivors, foes and profiteers. You'll definitely find some characters you will like but that depends on the campaigns you pay for. This is one of the few games where you can navigate most game menus WHILE loading into a social space or mission so you can optimize your wait time with changing your equipment or organizing your listed tasks at any time. While the stories can be good or tolerable, the game is at its best with the three-man dungeons and the six-man raids (majority of them are locked behind purchasable specific Dungeon Keys or deluxe editions) that will test you and your companion's competence, coordination and communication.

Now this is the part where I criticize this game's recent development and its core design. Destiny 2 has a very predatory monetized system when it comes to paid content, and it plays heavily into your fear-of-missing-out. The free-to-play content is very barren outside portal ops and player-versus-player modes. This game does a terrible job teaching players the overwhelming ability mechanics requiring knowledgeable folks that can explain them otherwise you will be fighting inefficiently or getting lost on what to do next. Timed tasks take a while to complete so if you are not a very active player this game does not respect your time and you will miss out on certain rewards. All of your characters in your three character slots do not share the story progression meaning anytime you want to use any expansion subclasses on a different class character you must replay (or pay for) that character's progression and additional ability unlock requirements. If you want specific cosmetics equipment without buying premium currency on horrendously priced cosmetics be prepared to either grind for a different cosmetic currency and wait on the weekly-rotated cosmetic section. As of this writing the player-versus-player game modes are sometimes filled with cheaters despite the BattleEye anti-cheat software being in place.

This section is just a middling heads-up. This game is hard, sometimes unfair, and that can provide a great challenge for those that invest in learning the mechanics and level designs. Destiny 2 has a free-to-play battle pass that provide resources and a paid battle pass which awards better resources as well as cosmetic items so you will have something to work towards to most of the time but at the end of the day it's padding for FOMO players. The game developers make controversial game design decisions periodically such as sunsetting expansion content and player gear though hopefully they stick to their word that they are done messing up player's inventory and their sunken time. Expect to ditching your outdated overpowered gear on occasion.

If you enjoyed the free-to-play experience of Destiny 2 and had to pick only one expansion, I recommend The Final Shape expansion which contains the fantastic finale of Destiny 2's main storyline (you should use the timeline tab to review all the summarized expansion details if you don't want to research online for the whole story) AND it gives all of your characters a subclass that allows you to mix multiple yet limited elemental abilities. If you want to invest into more subclass options then pick up the pleasant Beyond Light expansion then the divisive Lightfall expansion in that order for the other two darkness subclasses for your characters. I cannot recommend the gutted Forsaken expansion nor the 30-Year Anniversary pack but to only the diehard players as it only awards outdated legendary weapons and a few relevant exotic weapons. I do not have an opinion on the Year of Prophecy expansion but I know it contains two moderate-stakes campaigns that has the player base in an uproar. By the way do not bother picking up the standard editions of any expansion passes or else you will not get that expansion's dungeon key (additional dungeons and raid events) which can be bought separately at the premium shop, and it will be overpriced in comparison.

My closing thoughts is that Destiny 2 while having a lot of content can have very annoying gameplay mechanics that really need to be fine-tuned. Even if there are a lot of flaws, it is at its core a fun game that's always evolving with the community for as long as the servers are still online. The game expects a lot of your and your friends' knowledge, reflexes and cooperation to get the full enjoyment out of this series if you can push through some bad game design decisions and negative reputation but it is worth the rich world, presentation and stories it has built for the past 8 years (as of this writing). Regardless how anyone feels about Destiny 2, it is undeniable that it's a one-of-a-kind gameplay philosophy that no other games have successfully replicated and dethroned this sci-fi looter shooter...yet.

Heres the deal: the game has a lot of ups and downs. Honestly its hard to tell a prospective new player to try getting into it cause theres a lot of road blocks and plenty of things that many people (myself included) will complain about.

To start off here are the warnings for Destiny 2:

Every other update bungie is going to make a change no one likes, in time said change may become bearable or even enjoyable but typically they start out being inconvenient or annoying and we just have to hope they will make an additional change for the better.

The first 3 DLCs plus the original red war campaign were sunset and are no longer playable. Which is a big negative cause the Forsaken DLC is to this day considered one of, if not the SINGLE best DLC this game ever had

Furthermore if you want to get into the end game content and high level play you can expect to need to dedicate an absurd amount of time to this game, as you would with any MMO.

But for the few that can stick around long enough and get into this game, it also has a lot to offer:

Personally I think this game has the single best PVE gunplay I have ever felt in a game, ESPECIALLY for a looter shooter. The recoil feels reasonable, the control and damage values arent too over or underpowered in almost all the content, the enemy designs feel well thought out and intentional and most of all combat in this game is never boring, and if you think it is: its probably time to try a new build out pal :) (Side note: I dont like the pvp combat in this game but Im also just bad at it ;-; )

Additionally the movement feels clean, the abilities and build crafting are done wonderfully, the exotics all feel truly unique and almost every one of them can have a unique build solely focused around them. 
The Dungeons and Raids feel (generally) well planned and I enjoy a lot of the mechanics and puzzles they use in them and the coordination it requires. Admittedly this used to be more of a detriment but with the new systems bungie has implemented finding a group to play with has never been more streamlined. 

My honest advice to anyone who wants to give this game a try: try out what is available for free to see if you like the way the game feels, if you do: try picking up a couple of the older DLCs for cheap (Id suggest starting with Witch Queen, its a fan favorite) and see if you like the way the campaigns feel. If you do, I think you may just be a future Destiny 2 Player and if not, worst case is you tried a free game you didnt like. 
Give it a shot, It cant hurt :)

After scrolling through reviews and seeing so many negatives that said the same thing, I feel the need to point something out. Do people that put hundreds or thousands of hours into a game do so because they don't like it? If those same people had never seen or played Destiny before, do you think they would feel the same as a new player? Well, I AM a new player since I gave D2 a try for the first time about 4 months ago, and I have been addicted since. The story may be the most obtuse I've ever experienced, but all those complaints about how things were removed and changes were made and blah blah blah I have no basis for comparison, so I have no reason to feel cheated or betrayed. I don't think I have missed a single day since I "got it" after a rocky start.

Now, these reviews are to help people decide whether or not they should give this game a try. Do I recommend this game to someone that has never played it before? Oh absolutely. I'm not writing this review along side other people that have already put in years playing this game to whine about what it used to be, I'm writing this to the gamer that is curious about Destiny 2 but never tried it before.

There's something you need to know going in. This game is NOT kind to brand new players. The game, the community, even the youtube videos you WILL be watching for help at some point, they ALL talk to you in language you will not be familiar with and it will take time to understand. There are going to be people out there that are going to get too frustrated and they will quit, which I understand, but for those that are willing to put in the time to get past the noob hurdles, it is SO worth it, I promise you. This game has been going for almost a DECADE for a good reason. I kid you not, Destiny 2 has the best gunplay of ANY game EVER made, full stop period. And when I got frustrated at the beginning of this game, I looked EVERYWHERE for a game that had gunplay as good as D2 but it didn't exist. Borderlands was close, but still nowhere near the feel, the sounds, the overall satisfying EVERYTHING about the gunplay in this game, so I came back to it and started over, which led to my daily addiction of playing this game now that I "got it" (which is the best way I can describe it).

Still unsure about whether or not you should try this game? Here's the best part: IT'S FREE to an extent. There a multiple expansions, campaigns, etc which you can usually find bundled together for a VERY big discount all over the place, which for me was WELL worth it to get almost a decade's worth of content for less than $20. And that's not the end, there is STILL brand new content being released now! The most recent expansion was released not too long ago and there's a Star Wars inspired expansion hitting next month! These new ones come at new game prices, but if you're new to this game, you will be busy for QUITE a while going through so much content there will probably be discounts by the time you're ready for it.

So yes, I recommend this game. You can listen to the people that have played the game for years if you want to but ask yourself why they would put so much time and energy into a game they DON'T recommend. Few games will allow you to play for free to make up your own mind, so I'd suggest taking advantage of that. See you there, guardian!
